elements.content: Six new metal−organic frameworks have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions, in H2O or DMF/H2O, namely, [CoL] n (1), [Ni2L2(H2O)3] n (2), [CoL(bimx)1/2] n (3), [NiL(bimx)1/2] n (4), [MnL(bimx)1/2] n (5), {[CoL2(bimb)(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (6) (bimx =1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, bimb =4,4′-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)biphenyl, H2 L = 5-(4-pyridyl)-methoxyl isophthalic acid). These complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Complex 1 reveals a 2-fold interpenetrating three-dimensional (3D) framework with rutile {4 · 62}2{42 . 610 . 83} topology. Complex 2 possesses a 3D 4-fold interpenetrating framework with ths topology. In complexes 3, 4 and 5, H2L and bimx ligands link Co, Ni and Mn cations to generate 3D frameworks. Compound 6 possesses a 3D interlocked structure, with 2D structures intercatenating each other into a 3D structure (2D + 2D→3D) and with new topology. In addition, thermal stabilities, photochemical properties, and the magnetic properties for 1, 3, 4, and 5 are also discussed in detail.

elements.content: Six new metal−organic frameworks based on flexible ligand 5-(4-pyridyl)-methoxyl isophthalic acid have been synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In addition, the photochemical and the magnetic properties have also been discussed in detail.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the last two decades, there has been much interest in the area of crystal engineering of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) in view of their potential applications in adsorption, the photochemical area, and catalysis, as well as their variety of intriguing architectures. To get novel structures, much effort has been devoted to modifying the building blocks and to controlling the assembled motifs for required products via selecting different organic ligands. Besides that, several important factors also influence the construction of molecular structures, such as metal ions, pH, temperature, and solvent.

elements.content: So far, more attention has been paid to the flexible ligands. As we know, the flexible ligands have been used widely in the construction of MOFs with interesting topologies and attractive properties, because the flexible ligands have variable coordination modes and can adopt a variety of conformations according to the restrictions imposed by the coordination geometry of the metal ion to meet the coordination requirement of the metal ions, which can result in more topological structures than for the rigid ligand. Recently, we designed a flexible ligand, 5-(4-pyridyl)methoxyl isophthalic acid (H2L), owing to the following considerations: (1) The H2L ligand contains both carboxylate and pyridine nitrogen donors, which makes the ligand have more coordination modes (Chart ). (2) Pyridyl donor organic ligands have been used to obtain higher dimensional networks. (3) Workers of different backgrounds are paying much attention to the design and preparation of magnetic materials for the modern age. The syn−syn mode of the COO group of H2L may generate magnetic materials.

elements.content: In this full paper, we synthesize six new metal−organic complexes based on H2L ligands and another two auxiliary ligands, that is, [CoL] n (1), [Ni2L2(H2O)3] n (2), [CoL(bimx)1/2] n (3), [NiL(bimx)1/2] n (4), [MnL(bimx)1/2] n (5), {[CoL2(bimb)(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (6). In addition, we also describe the details of their characterizations and properties.

elements.content: The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received. H2L, bimx, and bimb ligand was prepared by literature methods. IR absorption spectra of the complexes were recorded in the range 400−4000 cm−1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets (5 mg of sample in 500 mg of KBr). C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The as-synthesized samples were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 TGA up to 750 K using a heating rate of 10 K min−1 under N2 atmosphere. Temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility data for polycrystalline complexes 1, 3, 4, and 5 were obtained on a SQUID magnetometer under an applied field of 2000 Oe over the temperature range 1.8−300 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received. H2L, bimx, and bimb ligand was prepared by literature methods. IR absorption spectra of the complexes were recorded in the range 400-4000 cm-1 on a Nicolet (Impact 410) spectrometer with KBr pellets (5 mg of sample in 500 mg of KBr). C, H, and N analyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (1.5418 Å), in which the X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV and 40 mA. The as-synthesized samples were characterized by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer Pyris 1 TGA up to 750 K using a heating rate of 10 K min-1 under N2 atmosphere. Temperature dependent magnetic susceptibility data for polycrystalline complexes 1, 3, 4, and 5 were obtained on a SQUID magnetometer under an applied field of 2000 Oe over the temperature range 1.8-300 K.

elements.content: A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H2L ligand (27.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 9 mL of distilled H2O, which was adjusted to pH = 6.0−7.0 with 1 mol/L NaOH. The final mixture was sealed in a 15-mL PTFE-lined stainless-steel vessel under autogenous pressure and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Large quantities of dark red-block crystals were obtained, and crystals were filtered off, washed with quantities of distilled water, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield of the reaction was ca. 55% based on H2L ligand. Anal. Calcd for C14H9CoNO5: C, 50.93; H, 2.75; N, 4.24. Found: C, 50.98; H, 2.81; N, 4.20. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(s), 3079(w), 2918(w), 2867(w), 2359(w), 1947(w), 1623(s), 1579(s), 1454(s), 1424(m), 1384(s), 1314(s), 1265(m), 1126(m), 1043(s), 960(m), 899(m), 885(m), 866(m), 816(s), 796(m), 776(s), 720(s), 650(m), 576(m), 548(m), 458(m).

elements.content: Single crystals of 1−6 were prepared by the methods described in the synthetic procedure. X-ray crystallographic data of 1−6 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. X-ray crystallographic data of these complexes were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solutions were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F 2 values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1 of the .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of 1-6 were prepared by the methods described in the synthetic procedure. X-ray crystallographic data of 1-6 were collected at room temperature using epoxy-coated crystals mounted on glass fiber. X-ray crystallographic data of these complexes were collected on a Bruker Apex Smart CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Structure solutions were solved by direct methods, and the non-hydrogen atoms were located from the trial structure and then refined anisotropically with SHELXTL using full-matrix least-squares procedures based on F  2  values. The hydrogen atom positions were fixed geometrically at calculated distances and allowed to ride on the parent atoms. The relevant crystallographic data are presented in Table , while the selected bond lengths and angles are given in Table S1 of the .

The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the P2(1)/n space group. In the asymmetric unit, it contains an independent Co(II) cation and one L2− ligand (Figure a). The coordination geometry about each Co atom is a distorted square pyramid, with four O atoms from four different carboxylate groups of four different ligands forming the basal plane and one nitrogen atom in the axial position. The τ trigonality factor is 0.011, indicating that the Co atom is in the square pyramidal coordination geometry. In 1, the H2L ligand acts as a “Y-shape” coordination mode (mode I of Chart ), the carboxylate group adopts a bismonodentate coordination mode to bridge two Co centers to form paddle-wheel SBUs, and the distance of Co···Co is 2.8777(5). The Co−O bond lengths are in the range 2.0337(15)−2.1658(15) Å, and the Co−N bond length is 2.0792(16) Å, which are all similar to those values found in other complexes. The carboxylate groups of the H2L ligand link the paddle-wheel SBUs to form a 2D layered network (Figure b), and the 2D layer links another 2D layer via the nitrogen atom from the H2L ligand to further generate an infinite 3D framework (Figure c). The dinuclear Co(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connected nodes with the L2− anions acting as 3-connected nodes. A topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as a rutile network topology, with the Schläfli symbol {4·62}2{42.610.83}. The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of an independent equivalent framework, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure d).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [CoL] n  (1)

The crystal structure determination reveals that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic crystal system of the P2(1)/n space group. In the asymmetric unit, it contains an independent Co(II) cation and one L2- ligand (Figure a). The coordination geometry about each Co atom is a distorted square pyramid, with four O atoms from four different carboxylate groups of four different ligands forming the basal plane and one nitrogen atom in the axial position. The τ trigonality factor is 0.011, indicating that the Co atom is in the square pyramidal coordination geometry. In 1, the H2L ligand acts as a "Y-shape" coordination mode (mode I of Chart ), the carboxylate group adopts a bismonodentate coordination mode to bridge two Co centers to form paddle-wheel SBUs, and the distance of Co⋅⋅⋅Co is 2.8777(5). The Co-O bond lengths are in the range 2.0337(15)-2.1658(15) Å, and the Co-N bond length is 2.0792(16) Å, which are all similar to those values found in other complexes. The carboxylate groups of the H2L ligand link the paddle-wheel SBUs to form a 2D layered network (Figure b), and the 2D layer links another 2D layer via the nitrogen atom from the H2L ligand to further generate an infinite 3D framework (Figure c). The dinuclear Co(II) SBUs can be regarded as 6-connected nodes with the L2- anions acting as 3-connected nodes. A topology analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as a rutile network topology, with the Schläfli symbol {4⋅62}2{42.610.83}. The potential voids are large enough to be filled via mutual interpenetration of an independent equivalent framework, generating a 2-fold interpenetrating 3D architecture (Figure d).

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray analysis reveals compound 2 crystallized in the monoclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit contains two Ni(II) cations, two L2− ligands, and three coordinated water molecules (Figure a). There are two different coordination environments of Ni(II) ions; that is, Ni1 is in an octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by five O atoms and one N atom. In the axial position, the two O atoms derived from water molecules. Ni2 is also in a six-coordinated environment: four oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups, which adopt a chelating coordination mode to the same Ni centers; these four oxygen atoms are almost in a plane. In the axial positions, there are one N atom and one O atom (O7) from the L2− ligand and coordination water, respectively. The Ni−O bond lengths are in the range 2.003(2)−2.196(3) Å, and the Ni−N bond lengths are 2.037(3) and 2.034(3) Å, which are comparable to those reported in the literature. Each L2− (takes coordination modes II and III of Chart ) links three Ni2+ cations to form a 3D structure (Figure b). To reduce multidimensional structures to simple nodes and connection nets, the Ni cations and L2− ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes. By analysis, compound 2 can be represented as a ths network topology (with the Schläfli symbol {103}). As in Figure b, in order to minimize the big void cavities and stabilize the framework, the potential voids formed by a single 3D network show incorporation with three other identical networks, thus giving a 4-fold interpenetrating network (Figure d).

elements.content: Complexes 3−5 are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group. Only structure 3 is described here in detail. X-ray diffraction reveals that only one crystallographically independent Co(II) center is contained in the fundamental asymmetric unit. The Co(II) sites are in “4 + 2” distorted octahedral geometry, defined by two nitrogen atoms and four oxygen atoms. The two nitrogen atoms from one L2− ligand and one bimx ligand occupy the axial positions, and four oxygen atoms coming from three carboxylate groups of the different L2− ligands locate in the equatorial plane. The four carbon atoms in the pyridyl ring (C9−C12) were disordered. The Co−O distances are in the range 2.027(2)−2.304(3) Å, and Co−N distances vary in the range 2.073(4)−2.159(4) Å, which are comparable to those values found in other reported similar complexes. As shown in Figure a, two carboxylate groups of the L2− ligand have two coordination modes (mode IV), one bidentately bridging two Co atoms in a syn−syn fashion and the other chelating one Co atom. The second building unit (SBU) is a dicobalt carboxylate moiety, with a Co···Co distance of 4.272 Å. The SBUs links by the carboxylate of the L2− ligands to form a layered network (Figure b); the N atoms also from the L2− ligands link the neighboring layer to generate an infinite 3D framework (Figure c). Besides, the bimx ligands also link between the adjacent layers (Figure d). Topologically, the L2− ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes with dinuclear Co(II) units acting as 8-connected nodes (Figure e). Analysis reveals the whole structure is represented as a new network topology (with the Schläfli symbol{42·5}2{44.56.68.75.83.92}).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of 3-5 

Complexes 3-5 are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group. Only structure 3 is described here in detail. X-ray diffraction reveals that only one crystallographically independent Co(II) center is contained in the fundamental asymmetric unit. The Co(II) sites are in "4 + 2" distorted octahedral geometry, defined by two nitrogen atoms and four oxygen atoms. The two nitrogen atoms from one L2- ligand and one bimx ligand occupy the axial positions, and four oxygen atoms coming from three carboxylate groups of the different L2- ligands locate in the equatorial plane. The four carbon atoms in the pyridyl ring (C9-C12) were disordered. The Co-O distances are in the range 2.027(2)-2.304(3) Å, and Co-N distances vary in the range 2.073(4)-2.159(4) Å, which are comparable to those values found in other reported similar complexes. As shown in Figure a, two carboxylate groups of the L2- ligand have two coordination modes (mode IV), one bidentately bridging two Co atoms in a syn-syn fashion and the other chelating one Co atom. The second building unit (SBU) is a dicobalt carboxylate moiety, with a Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance of 4.272 Å. The SBUs links by the carboxylate of the L2- ligands to form a layered network (Figure b); the N atoms also from the L2- ligands link the neighboring layer to generate an infinite 3D framework (Figure c). Besides, the bimx ligands also link between the adjacent layers (Figure d). Topologically, the L2- ligands can be regarded as 3-connected nodes with dinuclear Co(II) units acting as 8-connected nodes (Figure e). Analysis reveals the whole structure is represented as a new network topology (with the Schläfli symbol{42⋅5}2{44.56.68.75.83.92}).

elements.content: For compound 6, H2L and bimb ligands self-assemble with Co(NO3)2 in DMF/H2O to form an interlocked structure. It crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of compound 6 contains two cobalt(II) cations, two L2− ligands, one bimb ligand, and two coordinated and two free water molecules (Figure a). The two cobalt(II) cations have the same coordination environment, the Co cation is in an octahedral coordination sphere, in the equatorial plane, and there are four oxygen atoms, of which three are from two carboxylate groups of different L2− ligands and one is from the water molecule. The apical positions are defined by two N atoms, one from the L2− ligand (Co1−N1, 2.184(3) Å; Co1−N6, 2.196(3) Å) and another N atom from the bimb ligand (Co1−N5, 2.110(3) Å; Co1−N2, 2.122(3) Å).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[CoL2(bimb)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (6)

For compound 6, H2L and bimb ligands self-assemble with Co(NO3)2 in DMF/H2O to form an interlocked structure. It crystallizes in the triclinic crystal system of the C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of compound 6 contains two cobalt(II) cations, two L2- ligands, one bimb ligand, and two coordinated and two free water molecules (Figure a). The two cobalt(II) cations have the same coordination environment, the Co cation is in an octahedral coordination sphere, in the equatorial plane, and there are four oxygen atoms, of which three are from two carboxylate groups of different L2- ligands and one is from the water molecule. The apical positions are defined by two N atoms, one from the L2- ligand (Co1-N1, 2.184(3) Å; Co1-N6, 2.196(3) Å) and another N atom from the bimb ligand (Co1-N5, 2.110(3) Å; Co1-N2, 2.122(3) Å).

elements.content: The L2− ligands (mode II of Chart ) link three Co cations to form an infinitely wavy-like 2D sheet along the c axis (Figure b), and the bimb ligands link the equivalent layers to form a “Sandwich” structure (Figure c). Topologically, the “Sandwich” 2D structures intercatenated each other into a 3D structure (2D + 2D → 3D). A better insight into the nature of this intricate framework is provided by a topology analysis. The Co(II) center and L2− ligand can be regarded as 4-connected and 3-connected nodes, respectively. The whole structure can thus be represented as a new network topology (with the Schlafli symbol {63}{66}) (Figure d).

elements.content: As can be seen in the UV−vis absorbance spectra, the H2L, bimx, and bimb ligands show intense absorption peaks respectively at 230−250, 220−270, and 250 nm, which can be ascribed to π−π* transitions of the ligands. Compounds 2−4 and 6 show intense bands in the UV range at 350 and 800 nm (2 at 380 nm and 650 nm, 3 at 525 nm, 4 at 390 nm and 660 nm, 6 at 515 nm); these energy bands arise from d−d transitions. In the range at 300 and 350 nm, the energy bands are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transitions. The splitting of the 3d levels in the crystal field of the coordination compound results in d−d electronic transitions. But these characteristic bands in this range do not appear in the spectrum of the Mn2+ complex (Figure S1 of the ). A possible explanation for the phenomenon of Mn2+ could be found in its 3d5 electronic state, which is more stable.
elements.clean_text:
Photochemical Properties

As can be seen in the UV-vis absorbance spectra, the H2L, bimx, and bimb ligands show intense absorption peaks respectively at 230-250, 220-270, and 250 nm, which can be ascribed to π-π* transitions of the ligands. Compounds 2-4 and 6 show intense bands in the UV range at 350 and 800 nm (2 at 380 nm and 650 nm, 3 at 525 nm, 4 at 390 nm and 660 nm, 6 at 515 nm); these energy bands arise from d-d transitions. In the range at 300 and 350 nm, the energy bands are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transitions. The splitting of the 3d levels in the crystal field of the coordination compound results in d-d electronic transitions. But these characteristic bands in this range do not appear in the spectrum of the Mn2+ complex (Figure S1 of the ). A possible explanation for the phenomenon of Mn2+ could be found in its 3d5 electronic state, which is more stable.

elements.content: To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (, Figure S2). The TGA curve of 1 shows the network of compound 1 was decomposed quickly after 450 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. For complex 2, a weight loss of 11.3% is observed from 160 to 234 °C, which is attributed to the loss of the coordinated water (calcd 12%); then the structure was collapsed since 410 °C. For complex 3, no weight loss is observed until it reached 383 °C, at which the decomposition of complex 3 occurred. The TGA curves of 4 and 5 are similar to that of 3, which shows the networks of compounds 4 and 5 were decomposed quickly after 407 and 423 °C. In the case of 6, a little weight loss is observed from 45 to 110 °C due to the release of two lattice water molecules and two coordinated waters with a weight loss of 6.82% (calcd 6.88%); then the structure was decomposed since 393 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis and XRD Results

To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (, Figure S2). The TGA curve of 1 shows the network of compound 1 was decomposed quickly after 450 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. For complex 2, a weight loss of 11.3% is observed from 160 to 234 °C, which is attributed to the loss of the coordinated water (calcd 12%); then the structure was collapsed since 410 °C. For complex 3, no weight loss is observed until it reached 383 °C, at which the decomposition of complex 3 occurred. The TGA curves of 4 and 5 are similar to that of 3, which shows the networks of compounds 4 and 5 were decomposed quickly after 407 and 423 °C. In the case of 6, a little weight loss is observed from 45 to 110 °C due to the release of two lattice water molecules and two coordinated waters with a weight loss of 6.82% (calcd 6.88%); then the structure was decomposed since 393 °C.

elements.content: To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, XRD experiments were carried out for 1 and 3−6. The XRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in the (Figures S3−S7), and they show that the bulk synthesized materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

elements.content: The magnetic measurements were performed on polycrystalline samples of 1, 3, 4, and 5 using a SQUID magnetometer under an applied field of 2000 Oe over the temperature range 1.8−300 K. The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 in the forms of χM T and χM versus T is displayed in Figure . As the temperature cools, χM T continuously decreases from 5.73 cm3 K mol−1 at 300 K to 0.14 cm3 K mol−1 at 1.8 K, indicating antiferromagnetic coupling between Co ions. The value of χM T at 300 K is greater than the expected value of 3.75 cm3 K mol−1 for two isolated high-spin Co(II) ions (g = 2 and S = 3/2), which is caused by an unquenched orbital contribution arising from the 4T1 g ground state of Co(II). The magnetic susceptibility data were fitted assuming that the carboxylate bridges of the Co(II) ions form an isolated spin dimer system. The intermolecular magnetic coupling constants zj′ were taken into account, and the magnetic susceptibility from 7 to 300 K was fitted following eqs , which are deduced from the spin Hamiltonian, H = −2JS 1 S 2: Ĥ = − 2 J Ŝ 1 Ŝ 2 = − J ( Ŝ T 2 − ∑ i = 1 2 Ŝ 2 ) E ( S T ) = − J S T ( S T + 1 ) S T = 0 , 1 , 2 , 3 E ( S T ) = 0 , − 2 J , − 6 J , − 12 J χ M = N g 2 β 2 3 k T × 84 e 12 J / k T + 30 e 6 J / k T + 6 e 2 J / k T 7 e 12 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T + 3 e 2 J / k T + 1 = 2 N g 2 β 2 k T × 14 e 12 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T + e 2 J / k T 7 e 12 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T + 3 e 2 J / k T + 1 where all symbols have their normal meanings. The best least-squares fit of the theoretical equation to experimental data leads to g = 2.58, J = −3.97 cm−1, and zj′ = −1.80 cm−1 and has an agreement factor of R = 5.08 × 10−8. While the fit is acceptable, it must be cautioned that the value of J should be considered an upper limit because of the likely presence of zero-field splitting and/or spin−orbit coupling. These results indicate that there exists antiferromagentic interaction within the Co2 unit.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of complex 3, as a plot of χm T and χm vs T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility for one CoII), are shown in Figure . The value of χm T at 300 K is 2.61 cm3 mol−1 K. The χm T decreases gradually to 1.62 cm3 mol−1K at 1.8 K, indicating antiferromagnetic coupling between Co ions. The spin−orbit coupling observed in complex 3 can be estimated by zero field splitting (ZFS) effects of a single-ion of Co(II), and the coupling interaction between Co(II) ions can be given by the mean field approximation (zj′). The magnetic susceptibility from 7 to 300 K can be fit by an expression (eqs − ) for S = 3/2 systems with dominant ZFS effects, D: χ ∥ = N g 2 μ B 2 k B T × 1 + 9 e − 2 D / k B T 4 ( 1 + e − 2 D / k B T ) χ ⊥ = N g 2 μ B 2 k B T × 4 + ( 3 k B T / D ) ( 1 − e − 2 D / k B T ) 4 ( 1 + e − 2 D / k B T ) χ′ = χ ∥ + 2 χ ⊥ 3 χ = χ′ 1 − ( 2 z j′ N g 2 μ B 2 ) χ′ An excellent fit was obtained with D = −45.64 cm−1, zj′ = 0.25 cm−1, and g = 2.37 with an agreement factor R = 4 × 10−5.

elements.content: For compound 4, the experimental χM T value is 2.5 cm3 K mol−1 per Ni2 unit (Figure ), which is slightly higher than the expected spin-only value (χM T = 2.00 cm3 K mol−1, S = 1, assuming g = 2) for two high-spin Ni(II) atoms in each Ni2 unit per formula. Upon cooling, χM T steadily decreases from 300 to 1.8 K. The intermolecular magnetic coupling constants zj′ were taken into account, and the magnetic susceptibility from 1.8 to 300 K was fitted following eqs and . χ = 2 N g 2 β 2 k T × e 2 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T 1 + 3 e 2 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T χ M = χ 1 − ( 2 z j′ / N g 2 β 2 ) χ An excellent fit was obtained with J = −1.88 cm−1, zj′ = −0.36 cm−1, and g = 2.29 with an agreement factor R = 1.4 × 10−6. , This result also indicates antiferromagnetic coupling between two NiII centers through two carboxylate bridges.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , for compound 5, at room temperature the value of product χM T is 8.72 cm3 K mol−1, which is similar to the expected value of 8.75 cm3 K mol−1 for two isolated high-spin Mn(II) ions (g = 2 and S = 5/2). Upon cooling, the χM T value decreases continuously, reaching a value of 1.25 cm3 K mol−1 at 1.8 K. These features indicate an antiferromagnetic coupling. The magnetic susceptibility data were fitted assuming that the carboxylate bridges of the Mn(II) ions form an isolated spin dimer system. The intermolecular magnetic coupling constants zj′ were taken into account, and the magnetic susceptibility from 1.8 to 300 K was fitted following eqs and . χ M = 2 N g 2 β 2 k T × 55 e 30 J / k T + 30 e 20 J / k T + 14 e 12 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T + e 2 J / k T 11 e 30 J / k T + 9 e 20 J / k T + 7 e 12 J / k T + 5 e 6 J / k T + 3 e 2 J / k T + 1 χ ′ M = χ 1 − ( 2 z j′ / N g 2 β 2 ) χ where all symbols have their normal meanings. The best fitting gave J = −0.42 cm−1 and zj′ = −0.025 cm−1 with a reasonable g-factor (2.01) and R = 6.8 × 10−7. These results indicate that there exists very weak antiferromagentic interaction within the Mn2 unit.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six novel complexes by the self-assembly of H2L, bimx, and bimb ligands under different solvothermal conditions. All these compounds get the 3D supramolecular structures through intermolecular interactions. The results show that, owing to the H2L ligand containing both carboxylate and nitrogen donors, they have more coordination modes, which is good for diversity of the available complex structures. Under different conditions, they may take distinct coordination modes. Besides, the introduction of an auxiliary ligand (such as compounds 3 and 6) also plays an important role, which would enrich the diversity of structures and topologies. Subsequent works will be focused on the structures and properties of coordination compounds constructed by tripod ancillary ligands and an H2L ligand. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that compounds 1, 3, 4, and 5 exhibit an antiferromagnetic coupling interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized six novel complexes by the self-assembly of H2L, bimx, and bimb ligands under different solvothermal conditions. All these compounds get the 3D supramolecular structures through intermolecular interactions. The results show that, owing to the H2L ligand containing both carboxylate and nitrogen donors, they have more coordination modes, which is good for diversity of the available complex structures. Under different conditions, they may take distinct coordination modes. Besides, the introduction of an auxiliary ligand (such as compounds 3 and 6) also plays an important role, which would enrich the diversity of structures and topologies. Subsequent works will be focused on the structures and properties of coordination compounds constructed by tripod ancillary ligands and an H2L ligand. Magnetic susceptibility measurements indicate that compounds 1, 3, 4, and 5 exhibit an antiferromagnetic coupling interaction.

A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (29.1 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H2L ligand (27.4 mg, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 9 mL of distilled H2O, which was adjusted to pH = 6.0−7.0 with 1 mol/L NaOH. The final mixture was sealed in a 15-mL PTFE-lined stainless-steel vessel under autogenous pressure and heated at 130 °C for 3 days. Large quantities of dark red-block crystals were obtained, and crystals were filtered off, washed with quantities of distilled water, and dried under ambient conditions. The yield of the reaction was ca. 55% based on H2L ligand. Anal. Calcd for C14H9CoNO5: C, 50.93; H, 2.75; N, 4.24. Found: C, 50.98; H, 2.81; N, 4.20. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3420(s), 3079(w), 2918(w), 2867(w), 2359(w), 1947(w), 1623(s), 1579(s), 1454(s), 1424(m), 1384(s), 1314(s), 1265(m), 1126(m), 1043(s), 960(m), 899(m), 885(m), 866(m), 816(s), 796(m), 776(s), 720(s), 650(m), 576(m), 548(m), 458(m).

The yield of the reaction was ca. 48% based on H2L ligand. Anal. Calcd for C28H24N2Ni2O13: C, 47.11; H, 3.39; N, 3.92. Found: C, 47.19; H, 3.43; N, 3.87. The final mixture was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (15 mL) under autogenous pressure and heated at 100 °C for 3 days. cln_elements.content:
As can be seen in the UV−vis absorbance spectra, the H2L, bimx, and bimb ligands show intense absorption peaks respectively at 230−250, 220−270, and 250 nm, which can be ascribed to π−π* transitions of the ligands. Compounds 2−4 and 6 show intense bands in the UV range at 350 and 800 nm (2 at 380 nm and 650 nm, 3 at 525 nm, 4 at 390 nm and 660 nm, 6 at 515 nm); these energy bands arise from d−d transitions. In the range at 300 and 350 nm, the energy bands are assigned as metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) transitions. The splitting of the 3d levels in the crystal field of the coordination compound results in d−d electronic transitions. But these characteristic bands in this range do not appear in the spectrum of the Mn2+ complex (Figure S1 of the ). A possible explanation for the phenomenon of Mn2+ could be found in its 3d5 electronic state, which is more stable.

Thermal Analysis and XRD Results

To estimate the stability of the coordination architectures, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA (, Figure S2). The TGA curve of 1 shows the network of compound 1 was decomposed quickly after 450 °C, suggesting that the framework is thermally stable. For complex 2, a weight loss of 11.3% is observed from 160 to 234 °C, which is attributed to the loss of the coordinated water (calcd 12%); then the structure was collapsed since 410 °C. For complex 3, no weight loss is observed until it reached 383 °C, at which the decomposition of complex 3 occurred. The TGA curves of 4 and 5 are similar to that of 3, which shows the networks of compounds 4 and 5 were decomposed quickly after 407 and 423 °C. In the case of 6, a little weight loss is observed from 45 to 110 °C due to the release of two lattice water molecules and two coordinated waters with a weight loss of 6.82% (calcd 6.88%); then the structure was decomposed since 393 °C.
